detaileddescription.para: State of the context (bits 1 & 2 in the flags)

memberdef.argsstring: )(struct net_context *context, struct net_pkt *pkt, union net_ip_header *ip_hdr, union net_proto_header *proto_hdr, int status, void *user_data)
memberdef.name: net_context_recv_cb_t

briefdescription.para: Network data receive callback.

detaileddescription.para: The recv callback is called after a network data packet is received. This callback is called by RX thread so its stack and execution context is used here. Keep processing in the callback minimal to reduce the time spent blocked while handling packets.

parameterdescription.para: Network buffer that is received. If the pkt is not NULL, then the callback will own the buffer and it needs to to unref the pkt as soon as it has finished working with it. On EOF, pkt will be NULL.
a pointer to relevant IP (v4 or v6) header.
a pointer to relevant protocol (udp or tcp) header.
Value is set to 0 if some data or the connection is at EOF, <0 if there was an error receiving data, in this case the pkt parameter is set to NULL.
The user data given in net_recv() call.

briefdescription.para: Network data send callback.

detaileddescription.para: The send callback is called after a network data packet is sent. This callback is called by TX thread so its stack and execution context is used here. Keep processing in the callback minimal to reduce the time spent blocked while handling packets.

parameterdescription.para: Value is set to >= 0: amount of data that was sent, < 0 there was an error sending data.
The user data given in net_send() call.

memberdef.argsstring: )(struct net_context *new_context, struct sockaddr *addr, socklen_t addrlen, int status, void *user_data)
memberdef.name: net_tcp_accept_cb_t

briefdescription.para: Accept callback.

detaileddescription.para: The accept callback is called after a successful connection was established or if there was an error while we were waiting for a connection attempt. This callback is called by RX thread so its stack and execution context is used here. Keep processing in the callback minimal to reduce the time spent blocked while handling packets.

parameterdescription.para: The status code, 0 on success, < 0 otherwise
The user data given in net_context_accept() call.

briefdescription.para: Connection callback.

detaileddescription.para: The connect callback is called after a connection is being established. For TCP connections, this callback is called by RX thread so its stack and execution context is used here. The callback is called after the TCP connection was established or if the connection failed. Keep processing in the callback minimal to reduce the time spent blocked while handling packets. For UDP connections, this callback is called immediately by net_context_connect() function. UDP is a connectionless protocol so the connection can be thought of being established immediately.

parameterdescription.para: Status of the connection establishment. This is 0 if the connection was established successfully, <0 if there was an error.
The user data given in net_context_connect() call.

briefdescription.para: Function that is called to get the slab that is used for net_pkt allocations.

simplesect.para: Pointer to valid struct k_mem_slab instance.

briefdescription.para: Function that is called to get the pool that is used for net_buf allocations.

simplesect.para: Pointer to valid struct net_buf_pool instance.

briefdescription.para: Callback used while iterating over network contexts.

parameterdescription.para: A valid pointer on current network context
A valid pointer on some user data or NULL

briefdescription.para: Is this context is accepting data now.

simplesect.para: True if the context is accepting connections, False otherwise.

briefdescription.para: Set this context to accept data now.

parameterdescription.para: True if accepting, False if not

briefdescription.para: Is this context closing.

simplesect.para: True if the context is closing, False otherwise.

briefdescription.para: Set this context to closing.

parameterdescription.para: True if closing, False if not

detaileddescription.para: This function returns the state of the context.

detaileddescription.para: This function sets the state of the context.

detaileddescription.para: This function returns the address family (IPv4 or IPv6) of the context.

simplesect.para: Network state.

detaileddescription.para: This function sets the address family (IPv4, IPv6 or AF_PACKET) of the context.

briefdescription.para: Get context type for this network context.

memberdef.argsstring: (sa_family_t family, enum net_sock_type type, uint16_t ip_proto, struct net_context **context)
memberdef.name: net_context_get

briefdescription.para: Get network context.

detaileddescription.para: Network context is used to define the connection 5-tuple (protocol, remote address, remote port, source address and source port). Random free port number will be assigned to source port when context is created. This is similar as BSD socket() function. The context will be created with a reference count of 1.

parameterdescription.para: Type of the socket, SOCK_STREAM or SOCK_DGRAM
IP protocol, IPPROTO_UDP or IPPROTO_TCP. For raw socket access, the value is the L2 protocol value from IEEE 802.3 (see ethernet.h)
The allocated context is returned to the caller.

simplesect.para: 0 if ok, < 0 if error

briefdescription.para: Close and unref a network context.

detaileddescription.para: This releases the context. It is not possible to send or receive data via this context after this call. This is similar as BSD shutdown() function. For legacy compatibility, this function will implicitly decrement the reference count and possibly destroy the context either now or when it reaches a final state.

simplesect.para: 0 if ok, < 0 if error

briefdescription.para: Take a reference count to a net_context, preventing destruction.

detaileddescription.para: Network contexts are not recycled until their reference count reaches zero. Note that this does not prevent any "close" behavior that results from errors or net_context_put. It simply prevents the context from being recycled for further use.

parameterdescription.para: The context on which to increment the reference count

simplesect.para: The new reference count

briefdescription.para: Decrement the reference count to a network context.

detaileddescription.para: Decrements the refcount. If it reaches zero, the context will be recycled. Note that this does not cause any network-visible "close" behavior (i.e. future packets to this connection may see TCP RST or ICMP port unreachable responses). See net_context_put() for that.

parameterdescription.para: The context on which to decrement the reference count

simplesect.para: The new reference count, zero if the context was destroyed

memberdef.argsstring: (struct net_context *context, struct net_pkt *pkt, const struct in_addr *src, const struct in_addr *dst)

briefdescription.para: Create IPv4 packet in provided net_pkt from context.

memberdef.argsstring: (struct net_context *context, const struct sockaddr *addr, socklen_t addrlen)
memberdef.name: net_context_bind

briefdescription.para: Assign a socket a local address.

detaileddescription.para: This is similar as BSD bind() function.

simplesect.para: 0 if ok, < 0 if error

briefdescription.para: Mark the context as a listening one.

detaileddescription.para: This is similar as BSD listen() function.

parameterdescription.para: The size of the pending connections backlog.

simplesect.para: 0 if ok, < 0 if error

memberdef.argsstring: (struct net_context *context, const struct sockaddr *addr, socklen_t addrlen, net_context_connect_cb_t cb, k_timeout_t timeout, void *user_data)
memberdef.name: net_context_connect

briefdescription.para: Create a network connection.

detaileddescription.para: The net_context_connect function creates a network connection to the host specified by addr. After the connection is established, the user-supplied callback (cb) is executed. cb is called even if the timeout was set to K_FOREVER. cb is not called if the timeout expires. For datagram sockets (SOCK_DGRAM), this function only sets the peer address. This function is similar to the BSD connect() function.

parameterdescription.para: The peer address to connect to.
Callback function. Set to NULL if not required.

The timeout value for the connection. Possible values:
K_NO_WAIT: this function will return immediately,
K_FOREVER: this function will block until the connection is established,
>0: this function will wait the specified ms.
Data passed to the callback function.

simplesect.para: 0 on success.
-EINVAL if an invalid parameter is passed as an argument.
-ENOTSUP if the operation is not supported or implemented.
-ETIMEDOUT if the connect operation times out.

memberdef.argsstring: (struct net_context *context, net_tcp_accept_cb_t cb, k_timeout_t timeout, void *user_data)
memberdef.name: net_context_accept

briefdescription.para: Accept a network connection attempt.

detaileddescription.para: Accept a connection being established. This function will return immediately if the timeout is set to K_NO_WAIT. In this case the context will call the supplied callback when ever there is a connection established to this context. This is "a register handler and forget" type of call (async). If the timeout is set to K_FOREVER, the function will wait until the connection is established. Timeout value > 0, will wait as many ms. After the connection is established a caller-supplied callback is called. The callback is called even if timeout was set to K_FOREVER, the callback is called before this function will return in this case. The callback is not called if the timeout expires. This is similar as BSD accept() function.

parameterdescription.para: Timeout for the connection. Possible values are K_FOREVER, K_NO_WAIT, >0.

simplesect.para: 0 if ok, < 0 if error

memberdef.argsstring: (struct net_context *context, const void *buf, size_t len, net_context_send_cb_t cb, k_timeout_t timeout, void *user_data)
memberdef.name: net_context_send

briefdescription.para: Send data to a peer.

detaileddescription.para: This function can be used to send network data to a peer connection. After the network buffer is sent, a caller-supplied callback is called. Note that the callback might be called after this function has returned. For context of type SOCK_DGRAM, the destination address must have been set by the call to net_context_connect(). This is similar as BSD send() function.

parameterdescription.para: Currently this value is not used.

simplesect.para: 0 if ok, < 0 if error

memberdef.argsstring: (struct net_context *context, const void *buf, size_t len, const struct sockaddr *dst_addr, socklen_t addrlen, net_context_send_cb_t cb, k_timeout_t timeout, void *user_data)
memberdef.name: net_context_sendto

briefdescription.para: Send data to a peer specified by address.

detaileddescription.para: This function can be used to send network data to a peer specified by address. This variant can only be used for datagram connections of type SOCK_DGRAM. After the network buffer is sent, a caller-supplied callback is called. Note that the callback might be called after this function has returned. This is similar as BSD sendto() function.

parameterdescription.para: Currently this value is not used.

simplesect.para: numbers of bytes sent on success, a negative errno otherwise

memberdef.argsstring: (struct net_context *context, const struct msghdr *msghdr, int flags, net_context_send_cb_t cb, k_timeout_t timeout, void *user_data)
memberdef.name: net_context_sendmsg

briefdescription.para: Send data in iovec to a peer specified in msghdr struct.

detaileddescription.para: This function has similar semantics as Posix sendmsg() call. For unconnected socket, the msg_name field in msghdr must be set. For connected socket the msg_name should be set to NULL, and msg_namelen to 0. After the network buffer is sent, a caller-supplied callback is called. Note that the callback might be called after this function has returned.

parameterdescription.para: Currently this value is not used.

simplesect.para: numbers of bytes sent on success, a negative errno otherwise

memberdef.argsstring: (struct net_context *context, net_context_recv_cb_t cb, k_timeout_t timeout, void *user_data)
memberdef.name: net_context_recv

briefdescription.para: Receive network data from a peer specified by context.

detaileddescription.para: This function can be used to register a callback function that is called by the network stack when network data has been received for this context. As this function registers a callback, then there is no need to call this function multiple times if timeout is set to K_NO_WAIT. If callback function or user data changes, then the function can be called multiple times to register new values. This function will return immediately if the timeout is set to K_NO_WAIT. If the timeout is set to K_FOREVER, the function will wait until the network buffer is received. Timeout value > 0 will wait as many ms. After the network buffer is received, a caller-supplied callback is called. The callback is called even if timeout was set to K_FOREVER, the callback is called before this function will return in this case. The callback is not called if the timeout expires. The timeout functionality can be compiled out if synchronous behavior is not needed. The sync call logic requires some memory that can be saved if only async way of call is used. If CONFIG_NET_CONTEXT_SYNC_RECV is not set, then the timeout parameter value is ignored. This is similar as BSD recv() function. Note that net_context_bind() should be called before net_context_recv(). Default random port number is assigned to local port. Only bind() will update connection information from context. If recv() is called before bind() call, it may refuse to bind to a context which already has a connection associated.

parameterdescription.para: Caller-supplied timeout. Possible values are K_FOREVER, K_NO_WAIT, >0.

simplesect.para: 0 if ok, < 0 if error

briefdescription.para: Update TCP receive window for context.

detaileddescription.para: This function should be used by an application which doesn't fully process incoming data in its receive callback, but for example, queues it. In this case, receive callback should decrease the window (call this function with a negative value) by the size of queued data, and function(s) which dequeue data - with positive value corresponding to the dequeued size. For example, if receive callback gets a packet with the data size of 256 and queues it, it should call this function with delta of -256. If a function extracts 10 bytes of the queued data, it should call it with delta of 10.

parameterdescription.para: The TCP network context to use.
Size, in bytes, by which to increase TCP receive window (negative value to decrease).

simplesect.para: 0 if ok, < 0 if error

memberdef.argsstring: (struct net_context *context, enum net_context_option option, const void *value, size_t len)
memberdef.name: net_context_set_option

briefdescription.para: Set an connection option for this context.

simplesect.para: 0 if ok, <0 if error

memberdef.argsstring: (struct net_context *context, enum net_context_option option, void *value, size_t *len)
memberdef.name: net_context_get_option

briefdescription.para: Get connection option value for this context.

simplesect.para: 0 if ok, <0 if error

briefdescription.para: Go through all the network connections and call callback for each network context.

memberdef.argsstring: (enum net_ip_protocol ip_proto, uint16_t local_port, const struct sockaddr *local_addr)
memberdef.name: net_context_port_in_use

briefdescription.para: Check if a port is in use (bound)

detaileddescription.para: This function checks if a port is bound with respect to the specified ip_proto and local_addr.

simplesect.para: true if the port is bound
false if the port is not bound

detaileddescription.para: Is this context used or not
The address family, connection type and IP protocol are stored into a bit field to save space. Protocol family of this connection
Type of the connection (datagram / stream / raw)
Remote address set
Is the socket accepting connections
Is the socket closing / closed

briefdescription.para: Set custom network buffer pools for context send operations.

detaileddescription.para: Set custom network buffer pools used by the IP stack to allocate network buffers used by the context when sending data to the network. Using dedicated buffers may help make send operations on a given context more reliable, e.g. not be subject to buffer starvation due to operations on other network contexts. Buffer pools are set per context, but several contexts may share the same buffers. Note that there's no support for per-context custom receive packet pools.

parameterdescription.para: Context that will use the given net_buf pools.
Pointer to the function that will return TX pool to the caller. The TX pool is used when sending data to network. There is one TX net_pkt for each network packet that is sent.
Pointer to the function that will return DATA pool to the caller. The DATA pool is used to store data that is sent to the network.

briefdescription.para: Application network context.
